facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 14 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 14 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated July 11, 1961, of the Assam High Court in Civil Rule No. 64 of 1961. Naunit Lal, for the appellants.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated July 11, 1961, of the Assam High Court in Civil Rule No. 64 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated July 11, 1961, of the Assam High Court in Civil Rule No. 64 of 1961. Naunit Lal, for the appellants. The respondent did number appear. 1962. March 1.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on March 1, 1962 by VENKATARAMA AIYAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. March 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR, J.-The short question that arises for our decision in this appeal is whether the settlement by the Executive Engineer, Golaghat in the State of Assam.

facts.text: Ferry at Neparpatty settled by Executive Engineer, Golaghat on second respondent Phuka Chandra Gohain on January 23, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: the settlement by the Executive Engineer, Golaghat in the State of Assam. of the ferry at Neperpatty on the second respondent, Phuka Chandra Gohain, on January 23, 1961 was in accordance with the provisions of the Northern India Ferries Act, 1878.

facts.text: Ferry at Neparpatty declared to be a public ferry under s.4 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The ferry at Neparpatty has been declared to be a public ferry under s.4 of Act. On January 23, 1961, the Executive Engineer, Colaghat, put up the lease of the ferry for the year 1961-62 for public auction under s.8 of the Act.

facts.text: On January 23, 1961, Executive Engineer, Golaghat put up lease of ferry for 1961-62 for public auction under s.8.

anchor.surface_text: On January 23, 1961, the Executive Engineer, Colaghat, put up the lease of the ferry for the year 1961-62 for public auction under s.8 of the Act. At the auction, Tulsi Singh, the first respondent, gave a bid for Rs. 4,200/-, one Indra Deo Singh for Rs. 4,050/-

facts.text: At auction, Tulsi Singh bid Rs. 4,200/-, Indra Deo Singh Rs. 4,050/-, Phukan Chandra Gohain Rs. 3,000/-

anchor.surface_text: At the auction, Tulsi Singh, the first respondent, gave a bid for Rs. 4,200/-, one Indra Deo Singh for Rs. 4,050/- and Phukan Chandra Gobain, the second respondent for Rs. 3,000/-. The Executive Engineer then made the following Order - Sold to Shri Phukan Chandra Gohain

facts.text: Executive Engineer ordered: Sold to Shri Phukan Chandra Gohain at Rs. 3,000/- as the two other highest bidders fall in special List.

anchor.surface_text: The Executive Engineer then made the following Order - Sold to Shri Phukan Chandra Gohain at Rs. 3,000/-  Rupees Three thousand only as the two other highest bidders fall in special List. Under Rule 19 a , the acceptance of the bid by the companyducting Officer

facts.text: Chief Engineer approved the decision of the Executive Engineer dated January 23, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Under Rule 19 a , the acceptance of the bid by the companyducting Officer is subject to the approval of the Chief Engineer, and Rule 19 b  provides that he must, in doing so, ,consider among others whether the Officer companyducting the sale has taken into account and companysidered all the factors mentioned in Rule 19 above. The Chief Engineer approved of the decision

facts.text: Sale to second respondent confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Engineer approved of the decision of the executive Engineer dated January 23, 1961, and the sale to the second respondent was company firmed.

facts.text: On February 6, 1961, first respondent applied to Chief Engineer for accepting his bid and settling ferry on him.

anchor.surface_text: and the sale to the second respondent was company firmed. Thereupon, on February 6,1961, the first respondent applied to the Chief Engineer for accepting his bid and settling the ferry on him. By his Order dated April 7, 1961, the Chief Engineer rejected this petition.

facts.text: Chief Engineer rejected petition by order dated April 7, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: By his Order dated April 7, 1961, the Chief Engineer rejected this petition. On May 9, 1961, the first respondent filed in the High, Court of Assam a writ Petition under Art. 226 attacking the Order of the Executive Engineer dated January 23, 1961,

facts.text: On May 9, 1961, first respondent filed writ petition in High Court of Assam under Art. 226 attacking Order of Executive Engineer dated January 23, 1961, praying settlement on him.

anchor.surface_text: On May 9, 1961, the first respondent filed in the High, Court of Assam a writ Petition under Art. 226 attacking the Order of the Executive Engineer dated January 23, 1961, settling the lease in favour of the second respondent as companytrary to the Act and the Rules, and praying that it might be settled on him.

facts.text: Assam High Court set aside settlement in favour of second respondent as violative of s.8 and Rule 19, declared first respondent entitled as highest bidder.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges accepted this companytention and set aside the settlement in favour of the second respondent as violative of s.8 and Rule 19, and further declared that the first respondent was entitled to the settlement under Rule 19 as the highest bidder. It is against this Judgment that this appeal by special leave is directed.

facts.text: Government of Assam prepared lists of persons suspected or confirmed to be connected with smuggling activities.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the affidavit of the Chief Engineer that in pursuance of the policy of prohibition followed in the State of Assam, the Government or Officers of the Government have prepared ,-lists of persons suspected or companyfirmed to be companynected with smuggling activities, and that it was the policy of the Government number to grant taxi permit, stage carrier permit, fisheries, ferries etc.

facts.text: Policy not to grant ferries etc. to persons listed as suspected or confirmed opium smugglers.

anchor.surface_text: and that it was the policy of the Government number to grant taxi permit, stage carrier permit, fisheries, ferries etc. to persons who are listed to be suspected or companyfirmed opium smugglers. It is this list that if referred to as the ,special list in the order of the Executive Engineer.

facts.text: First respondent prosecuted under s.4 of Assam Ganja and Bhang Prohibition Act but discharged.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated July 11, 1961, of the Assam High Court in Civil Rule No. 64 of 1961. Naunit Lal, for the appellants. The respondent did not appear.

Under s.4., the State Government may, from time to time, declare what ferries shall be deemed public ferries. Section 8 of the Act is as follows The tolls of any public ferry may, from time to time, be let by public auction for a term not exceeding five years with the approval of the Commissioner,

concepts.interpretation: Empowers State Government to declare ferries as public ferries; Neparpatty ferry declared under this

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ame within the district or State, can speak the regional language, is financiall

anchor.surface_text: Section 8 of the Act is as follows The tolls of any public ferry may, from time to time, be let by public auction for a term not exceeding five years with the approval of the Commissioner, or by public auction, or otherwise than by public auction, for any term with the previous sanction of the State Government. The lessee shall conform to the rules made under this Act for the management and control of the ferry, and may be called upon by the officer in whom the immediate superintendence of the ferry is vested, or, if the public body under section 7 or section 7A, then by that body, to give such security for his good conduct and for the punctual payment of the rent as the officer or body, as the case may be, thinks fit. When the tolls are put up to public auction, the said officer or body, as the case may be, or the officer conducting the sale on his or its behalf, may, for reasons recorded in writing, refuse to accept the offer of the highest bidder, and may accept any other bid, or may withdraw the tolls from auction.

concepts.interpretation: Authorizes letting of tolls by public auction; officer may refuse highest bidder for reasons recorded in writing; discretion wide but not unrestricted, requires materials and consideration of factors under Rule 19

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: Art. 226 attacking the Order of the Executive Engineer dated January 23, 1961, settling the lease in favour of the second respondent as companytrary t

concepts.unlisted_description: Leasing of public ferry tolls by auction; refusal of highest bid

anchor.surface_text: Rule 19 framed under s.12 of the Act is as follows-- The sale shall generally be by auction to the highest bidder. The Officer conducting the sale for sufficient reason recorded in writing under his hand may refuse to accept the offer of the highest bidder or any bid. The Officer shall in accepting the bid consider the following factors among others- Whether the bidder is a native or domicile or an outsider. Whether the bidder has experience of the ferry business. Whether he has landed property in his own name within the district or State, can speak the regional language, is financially sound and of good conduct, etc.

concepts.interpretation: Sale generally to highest bidder; conducting officer may refuse for sufficient recorded reasons, considering factors like domicile, experience, property, language, financial soundness, good conduct; approval by Chief Engineer ensuring factors considered; rejection here invalid due to lack of materials

anchor.surface_text: Section 8, provides that the Officer conducting the sale may, for reasons recorded in writing, refuse to accept the offer of the highest bidder and accept any other bid. The discretion thus conferred on the Officer, is wide but not indefinite or unrestricted.

concepts.interpretation: Discretion under statute wide but fettered by requirement of recorded reasons, consideration of specified factors, and relevant materials; cannot be exercised arbitrarily

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of opinion that the decision of the learned Judges of the High Court that the rejection of the offer of the highest bidder is not in accordance with s. 8 or Rule 19 is correct. The result of this conclusion is that the authorities under the Act would have to be directed to consider the matter afresh and give a decision in accordance with law, but the learned Judges have proceeded further and observed that under Rule 19, the offer of the first respondent, being the highest, should be accepted.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contends that even on the view that the Order of the Executive Engineer dated January 23, 1961, is not in accordance with law, it was for the appropriate authorities to deal with the matter and make a fresh settlement and that the Court could not itself decide what is entrusted to the executive authorities under the Act. This, in our opinion, is correct.

anchor.surface_text: Section 8, provides that the Officer conducting the sale may, for reasons recorded in writing, refuse to accept the offer of the highest bidder and accept any other bid.
